item.title: Time Lords: The Science of Keeping Time
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: The Nerdist Chris Hardwick joins us for an upbeat discussion of clocks, calendars, and leaps in time.
item.description: The Nerdist Chris Hardwick joins us for an upbeat discussion of clocks, calendars, and leaps in time.
item.content:encoded:
Astronomical clock at the Zytglogge tower in Berne, Switzerland. Albert Einstein lived near the Zytglogge when working at the patent office in Berne. While travelling on a tram away from the tower, he thought if the tram were going at the speed of light, the clock tower would remain on the same time, while his own watch would continue to tick – proving time was relative.

The Nerdist Chris Hardwick and his trusty sidekick Matt Mira provide Dr. Who references and some timely humor for our show about clocks, calendars, and leaps in time. Anthony Aveni, professor of astronomy and anthropology at Colgate University, reveals whether the Mayan calendar predicts the end of the world in 2012, and provides insight into how early clocks and calendars were based not only on the Moon and Sun, but on Earth’s biology. Frank Reed, instructor of celestial navigation at Mystic Seaport in Connecticut, and Robert Seaman, computer programmer for the National Optical Astronomy Observatories, talk about why leap seconds are added to our fast-paced modern lives, and contemplate the future of time synchronization. From keeping Universal Time, to neutrinos that may travel faster than light, to geo-engineering the Earth into a global clock, take some time to consider how science sets the tempo of our past, present and future.

Co-Hosts:
Chris Hardwick The Nerdist.
Matthew Mira The Nerdist co-host.

Guests:
Anthony Aveni The Russell Colgate Professor of Astronomy and Anthropology at Colgate University in New York.
Frank Reed Instructor of celestial navigation at Mystic Seaport in Connecticut.
Robert Seaman Computer programmer for the National Optical Astronomy Observatories.

Contributor:
Bill Nye The Science Guy.

Songs featured in this episode:
Time After Time Cyndi Lauper.
Time is On my Side Rolling Stones.
Tik Tok Ke$ha.
Clocks Coldplay.
Time of the Season The Zombies.
Does Anyone Know What Time It Is? Chicago.
Times Like These Foo Fighters.

item.title: Spooky Science
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: Our Halloween special investigates the science of ghosts and other haunting phenomena.
item.description: Our Halloween special investigates the science of ghosts and other haunting phenomena.
item.content:encoded:
In our live show about dead people, Joe Nickell, paranormal investigator, talks to us from beyond our corporeal plane of existence—calling in from New Orleans, one of America’s supposedly most-haunted cities. Mary Roach, author of “Spook: Science Tackles the Afterlife”, provides a post-mortem on the history of spiritualism and modern-day ghost hunting techniques, while Phil Plait, the Bad Astronomer, devilishly dissects our favorite ghost movies.

Guests:
Joe Nickell Paranormal investigator.
Mary Roach Author of “Spook: Science Tackles the Afterlife”.
Phil Plait The Bad Astronomer.

Contributor:
Brian Malow Science Comedian.

Co-Host:
Eugene Mirman Comedian.

item.title: The Big Bang Theory
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: A hit TV sitcom about science geeks? Neil talks with the co-creator and science advisor for "The Big Bang Theory."
item.description: A hit TV sitcom about science geeks? Neil talks with the co-creator and science advisor for "The Big Bang Theory."
item.content:encoded:
The hit CBS TV sitcom “The Big Bang Theory” follows the adventures of four scientists—Sheldon Cooper (Jim Parsons), Leonard Hofstadter (Johnny Galecki), Howard Wolowitz (Simon Helberg) and Rajesh Koothrappali (Kunal Navyar). Neil talks with Bill Prady, co-creator and writer of the show, about why he decided to create a show about science geeks and the universal emotions that even theoretical physicists and engineers experience. Joining the conversation is David Saltzberg, professor of physics and astronomy at UCLA and science advisor to the show. From romantic relationships to religion to reflections on relativity, learn about the many ways “The Big Bang Theory” uses science to shine a light on society.

Guests:

Bill Prady Co-creator and executive producer of “The Big Bang Theory”.
David Saltzberg Science advisor to the show, and professor of physics and astronomy at UCLA.

item.title: Spaceward Bound
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: NASA astronaut Mike Massimino joins us to discuss the perils and promise of human space flight now and into the future.
item.description: NASA astronaut Mike Massimino joins us to discuss the perils and promise of human space flight now and into the future.
item.content:encoded:
After sending NASA astronauts into low-Earth orbit for 30 years, the Space Shuttle program is over. How will we now make the great leap into space? Russia’s Soyuz spacecraft will carry our astronauts to the International Space Station until NASA can complete the next generation crew vehicle and rocket. Meanwhile, companies such as Virgin Galactic are developing commercial flights so that, someday, everyone can see the stars shine above Earth’s atmosphere.

Neil talks with the final shuttle crew—STS-135—about what it was like to fly on the shuttle and their dreams of traveling far beyond our world. Also joining us is Mike Massimino, an engineer and NASA astronaut who flew on two shuttle missions to repair the Hubble Space Telescope. He talks about shuttle’s speed while in orbit (coast-to coast in only 11 minutes), the hazards to human health, and why walking in space is like Heaven off Earth.

Guests:

Mike Massimino Astronaut.
Crew of STS-135 Chris Ferguson, Commander. Doug Hurley, Pilot. Rex Walheim, Mission Specialist. Sandy Magnus, Mission Specialist.

Co-Host:

Chuck Nice Comedian.

item.title: Live at the Bell House (Part 2)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: In the second half of our live show at the Bell House in Brooklyn, Kristen Schaal, Scott Adsit, Eugene Mirman and our very special guest Alan Alda travel through time and higher dimensions.
item.description: In the second half of our live show at the Bell House in Brooklyn, Kristen Schaal, Scott Adsit, Eugene Mirman and our very special guest Alan Alda travel through time and higher dimensions.
item.content:encoded:
Eugene Mirman, Kristen Schaal, Scott Adsit, your host, Neil deGrasse Tyson, and Alan Alda at the Eugene Mirman Comedy Festival. Photo Credit: David Gamble

Emmy and Golden Globe-winning actor Alan Alda joins Star Talk Radio for our first live show, recorded at the Bell House in Brooklyn, New York on September 15, 2011 for the 4th annual Eugene Mirman Comedy Festival. Along with Kristen Schaal of the The Daily Show and Flight of the Conchords and Scott Adsit of 30 Rock, Neil, Eugene and Alan Alda travel through time and higher dimensions, discuss pseudoscience and the state of science literacy in the US, and take questions from the audience that explore just how weird and funny science can be.

Guests:

Alan Alda.
Kristen Schaal.
Scott Adsit.

Co-Host:

Eugene Mirman Comedian.

item.title: Live at the Bell House (Part 1)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: StarTalk Radio brought science in the house at the 4th annual Eugene Mirman Comedy Festival, with Kristen Schaal, Scott Adsit, Eugene Mirman and our very special guest Alan Alda.
item.description: StarTalk Radio brought science in the house at the 4th annual Eugene Mirman Comedy Festival, with Kristen Schaal, Scott Adsit, Eugene Mirman and our very special guest Alan Alda.
item.content:encoded:
Emmy and Golden Globe-winning actor Alan Alda joins Star Talk Radio for our first live show, recorded at the Bell House in Brooklyn, New York on September 15, 2011 for the 4th annual Eugene Mirman Comedy Festival. Along with Kristen Schaal of the The Daily Show and Flight of the Conchords and Scott Adsit of 30 Rock, Neil, Eugene and Alan engage in a hilarious discussion about aliens, black holes, asteroid Apophis and the end of the universe.

Guests:

Alan Alda.
Kristen Schaal.
Scott Adsit.

Co-Host:

Eugene Mirman Comedian.

item.title: The Music of the Spheres
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: From the physics of sound to the healing power of song, groove to the universal sway of music with guests Moby and Jonathan Coulton.
item.description: From the physics of sound to the healing power of song, groove to the universal sway of music with guests Moby and Jonathan Coulton.
item.content:encoded:
Ancient philosophers described the movement of the Sun, Moon and planets as “the music of the spheres” — the geometry of the cosmos conceived as proportional mathematical harmony. Today, science is revealing new ways music taps into ancient pathways in the brain, and technology is allowing music to be composed in new and innovative ways. Richard Melville Hall, better known as Moby, talks with Neil about the science of music, and how this intangible art has the power to move us physically and emotionally. Jonathan Coulton discusses writing songs about asteroid mining and the dwarf planet Pluto, and reveals that his song about fractals often makes him cry. Comedian Eugene Mirman is instrumental in providing some good vibrations for this symphony of science.

Guests:

Moby Musician.
Jonathan Coulton Musician.

Co-Host:

Eugene Mirman Comedian.

item.title: 9/11 Memorial
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: On this ten-year anniversary of the 9/11 tragedy, StarTalk Radio takes a look at the event and how it changed our lives.
item.description: On this ten-year anniversary of the 9/11 tragedy, StarTalk Radio takes a look at the event and how it changed our lives.
item.content:encoded:
The “Tribute in Light” memorial is in remembrance of the events of Sept. 11, 2001. The two towers of light are composed of two banks of high wattage spotlights that point straight up from a lot next to Ground Zero. This photo was taken from Liberty State Park, N.J., Sept. 11, the five-year anniversary of 9/11. (U.S. Air Force photo/Denise Gould).

On September 11, 2001, The United States was hit by the biggest terrorist attack in our nation’s history. Now, ten years later, we take a look back at the events of the day, talking to people from different professions — from a New York City firefighter to the creator of a TV comedy show — to discuss how the event affected them then and now.

Guests:

Dr. Irwin Redlener Director of the National Center for Disaster Preparedness.
Lt. Mickey Kross New York Firefighter.
Seth MacFarlane Creator of the TV show Family Guy.
Ronnette Riley Architect.

item.title: Making the Fur Fly
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: Although many people debate about the use of animals in science and civilization, few argue as adamantly against their use than our guest, Ingrid Newkirk, co-founder and president of PETA.
item.description: Although many people debate about the use of animals in science and civilization, few argue as adamantly against their use than our guest, Ingrid Newkirk, co-founder and president of PETA.
item.content:encoded:
Belka and Strelka, Soviet space dogs (on graffiti, Kharkov, 2008). Image credit: V. Vizu

Animals have been our companions and co-workers since before the dawn of civilization. We have eaten them (or products they make), and we’ve worn their skin and fur and feathers. Scientific progress has depended greatly on animal test subjects—from the development of many medicines to determining if we could survive a launch into space (the first astronaut was the dog Laika, sent up by the USSR in1957). We’ve even directed the evolution of many animals to better suit our needs, from pocket poodles to farm cows to lab rats.

In this modern day, with the impact raising livestock and eating meat has on the environment, as well as a growing understanding of the intellectual and emotional capacity of animals, many people are rethinking our traditional relationship with all creatures great and small. Ingrid Newkirk, president of PETA, argues that, thanks to new techniques, scientific discoveries still can be made “without the patter of little feet”.

Guests:

Ingrid Newkirk President and co-founder of People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals.
Dr. Peter Borchelt Animal behaviorist.

Co-Host:

Lynne Koplitz Comedian.

item.title: Revolving Around the Sun
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: See the Sun with new eyes as we discuss the many ways this ball of plasma illuminates our past, present and future.
item.description: See the Sun with new eyes as we discuss the many ways this ball of plasma illuminates our past, present and future.
item.content:encoded:
A coronal mass ejection from the Sun, as seen by the SOHO spacecraft. Image credit: SOHO Consortium, ESA, NASA.

What better time to talk about the Sun than during the summer? Once worshipped as a God, we now know the Sun is one of many similar stars in a relatively quiet region of the galaxy. Neil and his co-host comedian Chuck Nice are joined by Judith Lean, solar scientist at the Naval Research Laboratory, and Steve Keil, director of the National Solar Observatory, for an illuminating discussion of the ball of plasma around which our whole world revolves. From solar storms to calendars to climate change, learn about the many ways the Sun is the light of our lives.

Guests:

Judith Lean Naval Research Laboratory.
Steve Keil Director of the National Solar Observatory in Sunspot, New Mexico.
Bill Nye The Science Guy.

Co-Host:

Chuck Nice Comedian.

item.title: Through the Wormhole
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: Academy-award winning actor Morgan Freeman joins us for a light-hearted discussion of some of the deepest mysteries facing science today.
item.description: Academy-award winning actor Morgan Freeman joins us for a light-hearted discussion of some of the deepest mysteries facing science today.
item.content:encoded:
Academy-award winning actor Morgan Freeman joins the show to discuss his Science Channel program, “Through the Wormhole.” From the birth of the universe to the end of time, this TV series asks some of the most-long lasting and compelling quandaries facing science and philosophy. Morgan Freeman challenges Neil on what we think we know about the universe, and explains why he’s not afraid of an alien invasion.

Guests:

Morgan Freeman Award-winning actor and host of the Science Channel TV series, “Through the Wormhole”.

Co-Host:

Chuck Nice Comedian.

item.title: The Physics of Superheroes, the Sequel
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: Holy Δx Δp ≥ ℏ/2 Batman! Theoretical physicist Michio Kaku joins us for another discussion of superheroes and the amazing physics behind their incredible powers.
item.description: Holy Δx Δp ≥ ℏ/2 Batman! Theoretical physicist Michio Kaku joins us for another discussion of superheroes and the amazing physics behind their incredible powers.
item.content:encoded:
Doctor Manhattan of the “Watchmen” series has quantum mechanical superpowers. Image credit: DC Comics.

Doctor Manhattan of Watchmen can use quantum mechanics to travel through the universe and see into the future. Professor X of The X-Men can use electromagnetism to read your mind. Doctor Solar has power over the periodic table. “The Atom,” whose alter-ego is a physics professor, can shrink down to sub-atomic size thanks to help from a white dwarf star. (Funny how many characters in superhero comics have advanced degrees…).

These are just a few of the topics of discussion in our second superheroes show, which features more of Neil’s interview with James Kakalios, physics professor at the University of Minnesota and author of “The Physics of Superheroes” and “The Amazing Story of Quantum Mechanics.” Theoretical physicist Michio Kaku also joins us and explains why the freaky realm of quantum mechanics is a better reflection of reality than your common sense, and he predicts which superpowers will soon become possible thanks to scientific technology. Chuck Nice thinks it’s probably a good thing he doesn’t have superpowers, because otherwise he would make everyone “kneel before Zod.”

Guests:

Michio Kaku Author and theoretical physicist at City University of New York.
James Kakalios Author and University of Minnesota physics professor.

Co-Host:

Chuck Nice Comedian.

item.title: NASA and Nichelle Nichols
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: Famous for her role as Star Trek's Uhura, Nichelle Nichols discusses in part 2 of her interview how she also played a vital role in influencing the modern era of NASA.
item.description: Famous for her role as Star Trek's Uhura, Nichelle Nichols discusses in part 2 of her interview how she also played a vital role in influencing the modern era of NASA.
item.content:encoded:
Nichelle Nichols (“Lieutenant Uhura”) in 1977, talking to students about The Space Shuttle. Image courtesy NASA.

Through her ground-breaking role as Star Trek’s Chief Communications Officer Lt. Uhura, Nichelle Nichols became a passionate advocate to get women and minorities involved in real-world space exploration. Many were inspired to become astronauts thanks to her efforts, including NASA’s current administrator, General Charles Bolden. While she continues working through various endeavors to get young people excited about space, she hopes that the power of Star Trek will inspire us to keep pushing the boundaries of the final frontier.

Guests:

Nichelle Nichols Actress, singer, dancer and space advocate.

Co-Host:

Leighann Lord Comedian.

item.title: A Conversation with Nichelle Nichols
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: Nichelle Nichols discusses her role as Star Trek's Lt. Uhura, and the impact that had on her life and on society.
item.description: Nichelle Nichols discusses her role as Star Trek's Lt. Uhura, and the impact that had on her life and on society.
item.content:encoded:
Some might know Nichelle Nichols best from Star Trek, but this actress, singer, dancer and space advocate has much to say beyond her role in TV’s exploration of the final frontier. In this exclusive interview, she talks about how science fiction and Star Trek—and specifically her ground-breaking role as Chief Communications Officer Lt. Uhura—not only impacted her life, but also had an influence on society over space and time.

Guests:

Nichelle Nichols Actress, singer, dancer and space advocate.

item.title: Making Cents of Money
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: Suze Orman shares her street smarts about math, investing and the recent economic melt-down on our show about the science of finance.
item.description: Suze Orman shares her street smarts about math, investing and the recent economic melt-down on our show about the science of finance.
item.content:encoded:
Image credit: Boston University.

Show me the money! Best-selling personal finance author and TV host Suze Orman gives us her two cents about investing, the economic melt-down, and the impact of science on the financial world. Andrew Lo, director of the MIT Laboratory for Financial Engineering, guides us on a non-random walk down Wall Street and reveals the neurobiology behind financial transactions. Eugene Mirman coins some comic interest for a show that’s already an embarrassment of riches.

Guests:

Suze Orman Best-selling author of personal finance books, and host of the Suze Orman Show.
Andrew Lo Director of the MIT Laboratory for Financial Engineering, and chief investment strategist of the asset management company AlphaSimplex Group.

Co-Host:

Eugene Mirman Comedian.

item.title: Time Travel at the Movies
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: Travel back to the future for a discussion of time travel and the movies that depict such excellent adventures.
item.description: Travel back to the future for a discussion of time travel and the movies that depict such excellent adventures.
item.content:encoded:
Image credit: Universal Pictures / Amblin Entertainment.

According to Einstein’s Theories of Relativity, time travel is possible. No one is traveling back to the future yet, but it’s fun to imagine the many excellent adventures that would ensue if we could transport ourselves to different eras, as well as ponder the paradoxes and problems that might pop up.

Neil discusses the science of time travel with Phil Plait, the – “Bad Astronomer”. Along with comedian Leighann Lord, they take us on a journey through the many movies that have played with this possibility, including Planet of the Apes, Back to the Future, Bill & Ted’s Excellent Adventure, Star Trek, and the Terminator series.

Guests:

Phil Plait The Bad Astronomer.

Co-Host:

Leighann Lord Comedian.

item.title: Let There Be Light
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: Are you on our wavelength? Learn about the many ways the electromagnetic spectrum infiltrates our lives and illuminates the universe.
item.description: Are you on our wavelength? Learn about the many ways the electromagnetic spectrum infiltrates our lives and illuminates the universe.
item.content:encoded:
Saturn seen in ultraviolet (top), visible (middle) and infrared (bottom) wavelengths. Credit: E. Karkoschka (Univ. Arizona), NASA.

The universe is awash with radiation, from long wavelength radio waves to short wavelength gamma rays. The entire electromagnetic spectrum is not perceptible to us—the human eye can only detect visible light waves—but space telescopes and other technology act as our spy-glasses on the invisible realm. Michael Benson, Brian Abbott and Carter Emmart discuss the different ways they use data collected from the Hubble Space Telescope and our other mechanical eyes in the sky to reveal the artistic majesty of the cosmos. Neil and Lynne discuss light’s biography, from its birth in the Big Bang to the dying of the light at the end of time.

Guests:

Michael Benson Writer, filmmaker, photographer and exhibitions producer. Author of Far Out and Beyond.
Brian Abbott Manager of the Digital Universe atlas at the American Museum of Natural History.
Carter Emmart Director of Astrovisualization at the American Museum of Natural History in New York City.
Bill Nye The Science Guy.

Co-Host:

Lynne Koplitz Comedian.

item.title: The Political Science of The Daily Show
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: From Comedy Central's World News Headquarters in New York, Neil sits down with Jon Stewart of The Daily Show to discuss the comic (and cosmic) connections between the worlds of science and politics.
item.description: From Comedy Central's World News Headquarters in New York, Neil sits down with Jon Stewart of The Daily Show to discuss the comic (and cosmic) connections between the worlds of science and politics.
item.content:encoded:
Millions of people know Jon Stewart as the brilliant and hilarious host of Comedy Central’s, “The Daily Show”. Along with the show’s comedian correspondents, his ironic insight into the political issues of our time has made The Daily Show one of the most-watched news programs on TV. Now meet Jon Stewart, science geek.

Neil talks with Jon Stewart about his love for science, the difference between having scientists and politicians as guests on The Daily Show, and the cosmic connections that unite us all… because even New Jersey is made of star stuff. Charles Liu provides a scientist’s perspective on how politics has effected technological innovation and inquiry from the past to the present, from the Earth to the Moon.

Guests:

Jon Stewart Host of The Daily Show with Jon Stewart on Comedy Central
Charles Liu Professor of astrophysics at CUNY

Co-Host:

Leighann Lord Comedian

item.title: Climate Confusion
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: Extreme weather events dominate the news -- tornadoes, hurricanes, winter snowmageddons, floods. What is fantasy and what is reality in the cultural conversation about climate?
item.description: Extreme weather events dominate the news -- tornadoes, hurricanes, winter snowmageddons, floods. What is fantasy and what is reality in the cultural conversation about climate?
item.content:encoded:
A stop sign reading “stop global warming,” located at the intersection of 19th and Q Streets in Washington D.C., during the second North American blizzard of 2010. Image credit: AgnosticPreachersKid

The Mississippi Delta is experiencing historic flooding, tornadoes recently tore up towns in Alabama, and multiple blizzards buried the Northeastern U.S. last winter. These and other extreme weather events around the world are dominating the news, making people wonder whether climate change is the culprit for all these catastrophes.

NASA climatologist David Rind discusses the science of climate and weather, explaining what’s known and what’s still a mystery. Andrew Freedman of Climate Central comments on the media and politics focused on the issue, and filmmaker Charlie Lyons provides his take on “The Day After Tomorrow” and “An Inconvenient Truth.” Chuck Nice looks for the bright side of climate change: pre-cooked trout in overheated streams; dead cedar forests mean more material to build closets… what’s so bad about that?

Guests:

Andrew Freedman
Managing editor of online content and climate policy analyst for Climate Central
Charlie Lyons
Professor of film, filmmaker, TV producer, journalist
David Rind
Climatologist with NASA’s Goddard Institute for Space Studies

Co-Host:

Chuck Nice
Comedian

item.title: The Physics of Superheroes
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: Faster than a speeding bullet? More powerful than a locomotive? Neil deGrasse Tyson and James Kakalios discuss the science behind the amazing powers of our favorite caped crusaders.
item.description: Faster than a speeding bullet? More powerful than a locomotive? Neil deGrasse Tyson and James Kakalios discuss the science behind the amazing powers of our favorite caped crusaders.
item.content:encoded:
Image credit: Warner Bros. / capedwonder.com

Super heroes are popular because we dream about having their amazing powers—super strength, flight, X-ray vision, invisibility. Although seemingly impossible, many superpowers are based on real science. Join astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson in exploring whether science could let us see through walls like Superman, shoot webs like Spider-Man, disappear like the Invisible Woman, shrink like Ant-Man, stop bullets like Wonder Woman, run as fast as The Flash, or recreate Batman’s amazing technology. Physicist and author James Kakalios examines the physics of caped crusaders, while Lee Silver describes animals with abilities that could expand the limits of human biology. Meanwhile, mild-mannered Eugene Mirman wonders what it would be like to leap tall buildings in a single bound—or at least jump to the second floor.

Guests:
James Kakalios Physics professor at the University of Minnesota, and author of the book The Physics of Superheroes
Lee Silver Molecular biologist, Princeton University.

Co-Host:
Eugene Mirman Comedian.

item.title: Science at the Movies
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: Neil, comedian co-host Leighann Lord, and Phil Plait, the "Bad Astronomer," discuss The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly of science in the movies.
item.description: Neil, comedian co-host Leighann Lord, and Phil Plait, the "Bad Astronomer," discuss The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly of science in the movies.
item.content:encoded:
Movie poster for James Cameron’s blockbuster movie “Avatar”. Credit: 20th Century Fox.

From recent blockbusters like James Cameron’s, “Avatar” to the 1902 movie, “A Trip to the Moon”, science has been a steady source of inspiration throughout the history of film. But how much of the science presented on the silver screen is accurate, and how much is misguided or just plain wrong? From the mineral “unobtainium” in “Avatar”, to the genetics of “Jurassic Park” and “Gattaca”, Phil Plait, “The Bad Astronomer”, joins Neil and comedian Leighann Lord to review the Good, the Bad and the Ugly of science in the movies.

Guests:

Phil Plait
The “Bad Astronomer”

Co-Host:

Leighann Lord
Comedian

item.title: The Cosmic Chemistry of Cosmetics
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: Learn about the evolution of paints, powders, perfumes and other potions as we discuss the artful science of cosmetics.
item.description: Learn about the evolution of paints, powders, perfumes and other potions as we discuss the artful science of cosmetics.
item.content:encoded:
Image credit: Flickr user SpooSpa.

Derived from the Greek word kosmos, meaning “order”, “cosmetics” have been used since ancient times to re-arrange appearance. Although we no longer use poisons like belladonna or lead-based paints to enhance our looks, we still risk our health in the name of beauty with tanning beds, eyelash-enhancing eye drops, and injections of the neurotoxin Botox.

Neil and his comedian co-host Lynne Koplitz discuss historic and modern cosmetic methods, which even includes some NASA technology. Cosmetic chemists Steve Herman and Art Georgalas reveal some surprises about what the future holds to make sure we are all looking good while we keep looking up.

Guests:

Steve Herman and Art Georgalas
Chemists, Fairleigh Dickinson University

Co-Host:

Lynne Koplitz
Comedian

item.title: Are You Out of Your Mind?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: How do we know what we know? The brain is an amazing product of evolutionary engineering, but many influences can play with our perceptions.
item.description: How do we know what we know? The brain is an amazing product of evolutionary engineering, but many influences can play with our perceptions.
item.content:encoded:
Image credit: University of California, Davis.

The brain’s 100 billion neurons speak to each other by chemical and electrical signaling, and this complicated communication provides us with everything we know and defines who we are. But when it is led astray, we can end up with false perceptions, hallucinations, and many other misunderstandings of the world around us.

Oliver Sacks, author of best-selling books on brain disorders, including “Awakenings” which was made into an Oscar-nominated film, discusses some strange cerebral shenanigans that can shape our senses. Neil is also joined by Cara Santa Maria, a science educator with a background in neuroscience, and the comedian Chuck Nice, whose mother used to tell him that “he ain’t right in the head”

Guests:

Oliver Sacks
Neurologist and author
Cara Santa Maria
Science educator

Co-Host:

Chuck Nice
Comedian

item.title: A Violent Earth
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: Japan was recently hit by a triple punch: a powerful 9.0 magnitude earthquake generated a huge tsunami, which then critically damaged a nuclear power plant.
item.description: Japan was recently hit by a triple punch: a powerful 9.0 magnitude earthquake generated a huge tsunami, which then critically damaged a nuclear power plant.
item.content:encoded:
Image credit: National Geophysical Data Center.

On March 11, 2011, one of the most powerful earthquakes ever recorded struck the island of Japan. The 9.0 magnitude quake generated a huge tsunami, and a nuclear power plant located on the coast was damaged by the giant wave and began leaking radioactive contamination.

“We want to give you the science that’ll enable you to understand and interpret the news reports we’re getting from the Pacific Rim, says Neil. In this show, he talks with his colleagues at the American Museum of Natural History: Steven Soter, an expert on Earth phenomena and tsunamis throughout history, and James Webster, a geologist who specializes in volcanoes. They discuss how the planetary activity deep beneath our feet makes itself known through earthquakes, volcanoes and tsunamis. Neil also talks with Michio Kaku, theoretical physicist, about the science of nuclear power and the problems facing the damaged Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station in Japan.

Guests:

Michio Kaku
Steven Soter
James Webster

item.title: Cosmic Cuisine
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: What ingredients provide "The Right Stuff" for an astronaut's dinner? From BBQ to ice cream, we feast on food fit for the stars.
item.description: What ingredients provide "The Right Stuff" for an astronaut's dinner? From BBQ to ice cream, we feast on food fit for the stars.
item.content:encoded:
The Astronaut’s Cookbook by Charles Bourland.

From the early Gemini space missions to the future of Mars exploration, anytime humans venture beyond home they’ll need to have some snacks for the road. Dr. Charles Bourland developed food for astronauts for 30 years, since the days of the Apollo Moon landings, and he propounds on the preparation and packaging that goes into making food fit for space.

Chef Brian Ray, whose engineer father worked on the Apollo LEM and Saturn rocket, considers how cooking and restaurants would change in microGravity. Eugene Mirman reconsiders his desire to take a journey into space if instead of chips and BBQ ribs, he has to settle for irradiated beef and freeze-dried ice cream.

Guests:

Brian Ray
Co-executive chef of Buddakan; competed on the TV show “Iron Chef”
Dr. Charles Bourland
NASA consultant and food scientist. Co-author of “The Astronaut’s Cookbook”

Co-Host:

Eugene Mirman
Comedian

item.title: Appetite for Destruction
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: Paleontologist Peter Ward explains how life's tendency toward self-destruction has led to massive extinction events in Earth's history. What does the past -- and the smell of rotten eggs -- have to teach us about the fate of humanity?
item.description: Paleontologist Peter Ward explains how life's tendency toward self-destruction has led to massive extinction events in Earth's history. What does the past -- and the smell of rotten eggs -- have to teach us about the fate of humanity?
item.content:encoded:
Skull with a Burning Cigarette by Vincent van Gogh.

Out of all the planets in our solar system, only Earth has life as we know it. In fact, life has been on Earth for billions of years, and it permeates every nook and cranny of our planet. Some even think Earth regulates itself to make the environment more hospitable for life. This theory, called the Gaia Hypothesis by the biologist James Lovelock, is not supported by history, says the paleontologist Peter Ward. Instead, the fossil record shows that time and time again, life has suffered major population crashes and extinctions, often due to conditions caused by life at the time. Now human beings are poised to repeat the process. By pumping so much carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases into the atmosphere, we are changing the climate and starting a cascade of effects that could lead to our own extinction. Will our self-destructive behavior eventually bring us to our knees?

Guests:

Peter Ward
Paleontologist at the University of Washington in Seattle

Co-Host:

Lynne Koplitz
Comedian

item.title: A Conversation with John Hodgman
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: Expert-in-everything John Hodgman addresses a range of topics, from the possibility of alien or robot invasion, to what lobsters have in common with Star Trek's Spock.
item.description: Expert-in-everything John Hodgman addresses a range of topics, from the possibility of alien or robot invasion, to what lobsters have in common with Star Trek's Spock.
item.content:encoded:
John Hodgman – author, actor, humorist. Credit: David Shankbone.

“Will you donate your body to be stuffed and put on display (at the American Museum of Natural History)?” This is one of the many questions John Hodgman poses to Neil during their monumental meeting of minds. From the Mac vs. PC debate to “geeks versus jocks,” John and Neil provide more information than you require on the questions and challenges that face our age. Astrophysicist Charles Liu sits in the co-host chair this week, and comments on areas far beyond his usual expertise.

Guests:

John Hodgman
Actor, humorist and author of “The Areas of My Expertise” and “More Information Than You Require”

Co-Host:

Charles Liu
Professor of astrophysics at CUNY

item.title: Tour of the Solar System
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: Take a tour of the solar system with Mars Exploration Rover scientist Steve Squyres and planetary scientist Heidi Hammel.
item.description: Take a tour of the solar system with Mars Exploration Rover scientist Steve Squyres and planetary scientist Heidi Hammel.
item.content:encoded:
Artist’s Concept of Rover on Mars. Image by Maas Digital LLC for Cornell University and NASA/JPL.

Every now and then it’s good to take a tour around your own backyard. What a wondrous place our solar system is, from the terrestrial planets Mercury, Venus, Mars and Earth that orbit close to our Sun, to the gas giants Jupiter and Saturn that have moons with the potential for life, to the icy outer giants Neptune and Uranus, which are still hold many mysteries. (Pluto, although no longer considered a planet, is discussed too.)

Steve Squyres, the Principal Investigator for the Mars Exploration Rovers Spirit and Opportunity, talks about what it was like living on “Mars time” and why he feels like he’s been on the Red Planet. Heidi Hammel reveals her love for the ice giants Uranus and Neptune. They also discuss how astronomers have found evidence for hundreds of planets orbiting stars other than the Sun, leading many to think we’ll eventually find alien life in those far-distant solar systems.

Guests:

Steve Squyres
Professor of astronomy at Cornell University, Principal Investigator for the Mars Exploration Rovers
Heidi Hammel
Planetary scientist at the Space Science Institute in Boulder, Colorado

Co-Host:

Chuck Nice
Comedian

Contributor

Bill Nye the Science Guy

From Aristotle’s misguided meanderings to modern open heart surgery.

item.title: The Physics of Football
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: How are the universal laws of matter, energy and motion expressed on the football field?
item.description: How are the universal laws of matter, energy and motion expressed on the football field?
item.content:encoded:
Image credit: Derek Boyko.

Huddle up with geeks of the gridiron—New York Giants linebackers Jonathan Goff and Chase Blackburn, and Giants tight end Travis Beckum. Goff has true geek credentials with a degree in Mechanical Engineering, while Blackburn knows all the angles on the football field thanks to his degree in mathematics.

“Everything about football is applied physics—from blocking and tackling to the Hail Mary, says Charles Liu, astrophysicist football fan. Liu explains the physics of tackling, touchdowns, and tossing the ball, and tells us what it would be like to play football on the Moon. Comedian Chuck Nice provides color commentary for our Superbowl of science.

Guests:

Charles Liu
Professor of engineering science and physics at City University in New York
Travis Beckum
New York Giants tight end
Chase Blackburn
New York Giants linebacker
Jonathan Goff
New York Giants linebacker

Co-Host:

Chuck Nice
Comedian

item.title: The Out-of-this-World UFO Show
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: Have you ever seen mysterious lights in the sky, or glimpsed an alien spacecraft? This show provides a probing yet playful discussion about Unidentified Flying Objects.
item.description: Have you ever seen mysterious lights in the sky, or glimpsed an alien spacecraft? This show provides a probing yet playful discussion about Unidentified Flying Objects.
item.content:encoded:
Lenticular cloud, New Mexico, USA. Image credit: Brandy Jenkins.

There are thousands of sightings of Unidentified Flying Objects every year, but why do so many people assume they are aliens visiting from another galaxy? Most UFOs end up being identified as clouds or other natural phenomena, or man-made objects such as balloons or aircraft.

Neil and comedian co-host Eugene Mirman discuss the tricks the human brain can play on our perception, the physics of space travel, and science fiction movies that depict alien spaceships. Neil interviews James McGaha, UFO investigator, about the many unusual things that can appear in the sky, and SETI researcher Seth Shostak calls in for a chat about alien visitations. With science as your co-pilot, the truth is always out there.

Guests:

James McGaha
Director of the Grasslands Observatory
Seth Shostak
Astronomer with the SETI Institute

Co-Host:

Eugene Mirman
Comedian

item.title: Wit and Wisdom about Wine
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: When tasting the first sparkling champagne, Benedictine monk Dom Perignon supposedly said, "Come quickly, I am drinking the stars!" It's more likely the quote originates from a late 19th century advertisement, but the sentiment is universally appealing.
item.description: When tasting the first sparkling champagne, Benedictine monk Dom Perignon supposedly said, "Come quickly, I am drinking the stars!" It's more likely the quote originates from a late 19th century advertisement, but the sentiment is universally appealing.
item.content:encoded:
Image credit: Jon Sullivan.

Wine has been around since the dawn of civilization, dating back at least 8,000 years. In this spirited toast to the science of wine, Neil and co-host comedian Lynne Koplitz discuss the history of wine production and the technology that will change wine in the future. Other topics include the physics of champagne bottles and glasses, the hazards of serving wine to astronauts, and biodynamic vineyards that look to the cosmos for help in growing the perfect grape.

Wine Jedi Jennifer Simonetti-Bryan sabers a bottle of champagne and sheds light on all the elements that go into creating a fine wine, while comedian Brian Malow explains how the chemistry of wine has saved countless lives. Imbibing in this intoxicating program will not give you a hangover, but this science is far from sober.

Guests:

Jennifer Simonetti-Bryan
Master of Wine

Co-Host:

Lynne Koplitz
Comedian

Contributor

Brian Malow
Earth’s premier science comedian

item.title: The International Space Station: A Space Age Cathedral
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: While cathedrals give people a place to contemplate Heaven from our place here on Earth, astronauts on the ISS can view Earth from "the heavens" above. This show highlights the many ways the ISS is like a modern-day cathedral.
item.description: While cathedrals give people a place to contemplate Heaven from our place here on Earth, astronauts on the ISS can view Earth from "the heavens" above. This show highlights the many ways the ISS is like a modern-day cathedral.
item.content:encoded:
Peering out of the cupola window of the International Space Station, astronaut Tracy Caldwell Dyson looks down on the planet on which we were all born. People looking up at that moment may have seen the ISS drifting overhead as a bright point of light. Credit: Expedition 24 crew, NASA.

At an estimated cost of 100 billion dollars, the International Space Station may be the most expensive object ever constructed. Orbiting the Earth at 17,000 miles per hour (or 16 orbits per day), the ISS is larger than a football field and will weigh 400 metric tons when completed. Over 12 years, astronauts have spent more than 1,000 hours walking in space to piece together the many parts that make up this unique structure in the sky.

Neil talks with astronaut Shannon Walker while she’s still onboard the ISS and speaks with Senator John Glenn about the future of the station. Architect Jim Polshek brings us back down to Earth with the practical realities of creating buildings large and small. From the history and methods of cathedral building, to the beauty and hazards of windows, to how space affects a spider’s ability to weave a web, learn how this cosmic construction can change the way we see the world.

Guests:

Jim Polshek
Architect
Shannon Walker
NASA astronaut
Senator John Glenn
Astronaut, Senator, first American to orbit Earth

Co-Host:

Chuck Nice
Comedian

item.title: Holiday Lights
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: For our holiday show, Neil and his comedian co-hosts discuss the constellations of the winter sky, the star of Bethlehem, and the physics of Santa. Seth MacFarlane and other special guests call in to comment on the science of the season.
item.description: For our holiday show, Neil and his comedian co-hosts discuss the constellations of the winter sky, the star of Bethlehem, and the physics of Santa. Seth MacFarlane and other special guests call in to comment on the science of the season.
item.content:encoded:
(Credit and Copyright: T. Credner)

To kids from one to ninety-two, the happenings of the holidays give us plenty of reasons to keep looking up. Neil talks about winter sky constellations, Santa’s sleigh ride, and the astronomy behind the Star of Bethlehem with comedian co-hosts Chuck Nice and Leighann Lord. The stars are brightly shining as Family Guy creator Seth MacFarlane, Vatican astronomer Brother Guy Consolmagno, and Bill Nye the Science Guy drop in on the festivities. Tis the season for some spectacular science.

Guests:

Seth MacFarlane
Comedian
Brother Guy Consolmagno
Curator of meteorites at the Vatican Observatory
Bill Nye
Scientist, engineer, comedian, author, and inventor, host Bill Nye the Science Guy

Co-Host:

Leighann Lord
Comedienne
Chuck Nice
Comedian

item.title: Science is Fierce
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: Do sci-fi classics like Star Trek provide a glimpse into future trends and styles? Neil chats with stylist James Aguiar about the science fiction and facts of fashion.
item.description: Do sci-fi classics like Star Trek provide a glimpse into future trends and styles? Neil chats with stylist James Aguiar about the science fiction and facts of fashion.
item.content:encoded:
Lieutenant Uhura conducted intergalactic communications in supreme Star Trek style. (Courtesy CBS/Paramount)

Like science, fashion is always evolving, each new idea potentially changing our lives from drab to fabulous. Fashion can project a glamorous image, or—in the case of astronaut spacesuits and NASA-designed swimwear—push us to exceed our hum-drum human limits. Neil and co-host Lynne Koplitz become wrapped up in cutting-edge fashion concepts like self-heating clothing, aromatic fabrics and dissolving dresses. James Aguiar judges the influence of sci-fi classics like Star Trek on future trends and styles, and reveals the surprising sources for fashion’s inspiration.

Guests:
James Aguiar Fashion stylist of the TV show Full Frontal Fashion.

Co-Host:
Lynne Koplitz Comedienne.

item.title: An Alien’s Guide to Earth
item.dc:creator: admin
item.itunes:author: Startalk
item.itunes:subtitle: Jon Stewart is the first guest of the new season. He and Neil discuss the Daily Show book, Earth: A Visitor's Guide to the Human Race.
item.description: Jon Stewart is the first guest of the new season. He and Neil discuss the Daily Show book, Earth: A Visitor's Guide to the Human Race.
item.content:encoded:
Jon Stewart is the first guest of the new season. He and Neil discuss the Daily Show book, Earth: A Visitor’s Guide to the Human Race.

Addressed to aliens who visit our planet long after humans have gone extinct, this book is all that’s left to document the world as we know it. Lynne Koplitz returns as Neil’s co-host to investigate this hilarious encyclopedia humanica.

Guests:
Jon Stewart Host of The Daily Show with Jon Stewart on Comedy Central.

Co-Host:
Lynne Koplitz< Comedienne.
